CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: [16][17][18][19][20] In comparison with the C-C bond , a longer C-Si bond shows less steric hindrance , which directly resulted in better π-π stacking along the conjugated polymer backbones.

Let's think step by step.

1. C-C bond - This is a "Material Name" entity. It refers to a chemical bond between two carbon atoms.
2. C-Si bond - This is also a "Material Name" entity. It refers to a chemical bond between a carbon atom and a silicon atom.
3. Conjugated polymer backbones - This is a "Material Name" entity. It refers to the main chain of a polymer that has alternating double and single bonds, allowing for the delocalization of electrons.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. C-C bond
2. C-Si bond
3. Conjugated polymer backbones

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| C-C bond |
| C-Si bond |
| Conjugated polymer backbones |

PN.content:
Please identify the "Property Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: [16][17][18][19][20] In comparison with the C-C bond , a longer C-Si bond shows less steric hindrance , which directly resulted in better π-π stacking along the conjugated polymer backbones.

Let's think step by step.

1. C-C bond - This is a "Property Name" entity as it refers to a type of chemical bond between two carbon atoms.
2. C-Si bond - This is also a "Property Name" entity as it refers to a type of chemical bond between a carbon atom and a silicon atom.
3. steric hindrance - This is a "Property Name" entity as it refers to the phenomenon where the size of nearby atoms or groups of atoms can interfere with the arrangement or interaction of other atoms or groups of atoms.
4. π-π stacking - This is a "Property Name" entity as it refers to a type of interaction between aromatic rings or other π-systems, where the rings or systems stack on top of each other in a parallel orientation.
5. conjugated polymer backbones - This is not a "Property Name" entity, but rather a description of a type of molecule.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Property.

1. C-C bond - Material Property
2. C-Si bond - Material Property
3. steric hindrance - Material Property
4. π-π stacking - Material Property

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Name |
| --- |
| C-C bond |
| C-Si bond |
| steric hindrance |
| π-π stacking |

PV.content:
Please identify the "Property Value" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: [16][17][18][19][20] In comparison with the C-C bond , a longer C-Si bond shows less steric hindrance , which directly resulted in better π-π stacking along the conjugated polymer backbones.

Let's think step by step.

1. "longer C-Si bond": The length of the C-Si bond is a property value.
2. "less steric hindrance": The amount of steric hindrance is a property value.
3. "better π-π stacking": The degree of π-π stacking is a property value.

These entities are property values because they describe the properties or characteristics of the chemical bonds and interactions in the given paragraph.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

1. Longer C-Si bond (the length of a bond is a material property)
2. Less steric hindrance (the degree of steric hindrance is a material property)
3. Better π-π stacking (the degree of π-π stacking is a material property)

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Value |
| --- |
| longer C-Si bond |
| less steric hindrance |
| better π-π stacking |
